questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 12-month history of upper abdominal pain. The pain is worse after eating, which she reports as 7 out of 10 in intensity. Over the last year, she has also had nausea, heartburn, and multiple episodes of diarrhea with no blood or mucus. Eight months ago, she underwent an upper endoscopy, which showed several ulcers in the gastric antrum, the pylorus, and the duodenum, as well as thick gastric folds. The biopsies from these ulcers were negative for H. pylori. Current medications include pantoprazole and over-the-counter antacids. She appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation in the epigastric and umbilical areas. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. A repeat upper endoscopy shows persistent gastric and duodenal ulceration with minimal bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The secretin stimulation test (SST) is a confirmatory test for gastrinoma, which is the most likely diagnosis based on this patient's clinical presentation and her endoscopy findings (PUD resistant to medical therapy). However, SST is not the best initial test for diagnosing gastrinoma, as it is less sensitive than other screening modalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Although a urea breath test is a viable screening tool for Helicobacter pylori, the gold standard for detecting H. pylori is histopathologic evaluation of endoscopic biopsies. The results of this patient's biopsy were negative. Performing a screening test after the confirmatory test is therefore unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

24-hour esophageal pH monitoring is used to confirm gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which this patient most likely has based on her persistent heartburn. However, her condition is refractory to medical therapy, which raises suspicion of another underlying etiology not detected on endoscopy. Although 24-hour esophageal pH monitoring would confirm the presence of GERD in this patient, it wouldn't offer any additional diagnostic clues.

D) CORRECT:

Determining the fasting serum gastrin level after discontinuation of proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is the best initial test for diagnosing gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). A 10-fold increase in gastrin levels is conclusive evidence of a gastrinoma. A gastrin-producing tumor is suggested by the patient's extended course of symptoms and multiple peptic ulcers that have been refractory to PPI therapy. Even though gastrinomas are a rare cause of PUD, more than 95% of patients with gastrinoma present with PUD. More frequent causes of PUD, such as infection with Helicobacter pylori or long-term use of NSAIDs can be ruled out based on patient history.

In addition to determining the fasting serum gastrin level, this patient's gastric pH should also be measured. Elevated serum gastrin and a pH of < 2 are indicative of a gastrinoma. When pH is > 2, other etiologies of elevated gastrin should be ruled out (e.g., PPI ingestion).

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's endoscopy findings are consistent with a gastrin-secreting tumor, which would explain why the trial of medical therapy did not improve her symptoms. Even though abdominal CT is generally a preferred imaging study for detecting the location and extent of tumors, it also exposes the patient to potentially unnecessary radiation. Additionally, gastrinomas arising from the pancreas are often difficult to visualize on a CT scan. To increase the pretest probability of imaging studies, the diagnosis should first be confirmed with another test.
questions.hint: Therapy-resistant peptic ulcer disease (PUD) always warrants further diagnostic workup and raises suspicion for gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). Inactivation of pancreatic enzymes by gastric acid hypersecretion can cause diarrhea.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty walking and dizziness for the past 2 weeks. She has also had fatigue, heartburn, and diarrhea for 4 months. The stools are foul-smelling and do not flush easily. Over the past 4 months, she has had a 2.2-kg (5-lb) weight loss. Her only medication is an over-the-counter antacid. Her mother has autoimmune thyroid disease and Crohn disease. She is 150 cm (4 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 43 kg (95 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a wide-based gait. Muscle strength and tone are normal in all extremities. Rapid alternating movement of the hands is impaired. The abdomen is soft and there is mild tenderness to palpation in the epigastric area. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.1 mg/dL, and levels of vitamin E and vitamin D are decreased. An upper endoscopy shows several ulcers in the gastric antrum and the descending duodenum. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: T. whipplei infiltration of intestinal villi

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoantibodies against the intestinal mucosa are associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), e.g., pANCA in ulcerative colitis, which can present with malabsorption, diarrhea, weight loss, and anemia. In addition, this patient is at increased risk for Crohn disease because of her positive family history. However, she lacks other typical features of IBD such as abscesses and fistulas (Crohn disease) and bloody diarrhea and tenesmus (ulcerative colitis). IBD also fails to explain the PUD in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

A gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) causes a large volume of gastric acid to be produced, which decreases intestinal pH. Pancreatic lipases, which require an alkaline environment to function, are inactivated and can no longer emulsify fats. This may result in a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (e.g., vitamin E), causing neuromuscular disorders, such as ataxia. In addition, increased gastric acid leads to the development of PUD. Finally, gastrin acts directly on the intestine and prevents sodium and water reabsorption, resulting in secretory diarrhea. Treatment of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) includes proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole) and H2 antagonists (e.g., ranitidine) in order to reduce acid production. Octreotide (a somatostatin analog) may be used in refractory cases.

C) INCORRECT:

Tropheryma whipplei infiltration of intestinal villi causes Whipple disease, which can present with malabsorption, steatorrhea, and neurological symptoms such as ataxia. However, Whipple disease is rare and mainly affects men 48–54 years of age. Moreover, most cases of Whipple disease are associated with enteropathic arthritis (classically preceding gastrointestinal symptoms) and can also be associated with sacroiliitis, fever, or polyserositis. Finally, PUD points to another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

An intestinal inflammatory reaction to gluten is seen in celiac disease (CD). CD can present with malabsorption symptoms such as steatorrhea, anemia, and weight loss, but it would not explain this patient's PUD. CD also often occurs in association with extraintestinal features, including dermatological symptoms (e.g., dermatitis herpetiformis) and endocrine symptoms (e.g., autoimmune thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus).

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired intestinal amino acid transport is seen in Hartnup disease. While niacin deficiency from reduced tryptophan can cause diarrhea (from pellagra) and neurologic symptoms such as ataxia, these symptoms are usually associated with dermatitis, and neurologic symptoms would typically include confusion and dementia. Furthermore, Hartnup disease would not explain the PUD in this patient.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

F) INCORRECT:

Small intestine bacterial overgrowth can present with diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and malabsorption. However, it is most commonly caused by complications of abdominal surgery (such as blind loop syndrome) and gastrointestinal motility disorders. Moreover, the PUD in this patient points to another diagnosis.
questions.hint: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) that also involves the descending duodenum in combination with steatorrhea with malabsorption (anemia with fatigue, fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, weight loss) make gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) the most likely diagnosis. Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as ataxia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of upper abdominal pain. During this period, he has also had nausea, heartburn, and multiple episodes of diarrhea with no blood or mucus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 18 years. He does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Current medications include an antacid. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation in the epigastric and umbilical areas. Upper endoscopy shows several ulcers in the duodenum and the upper jejunum as well as thick gastric folds. Gastric pH is < 2. Biopsies from the ulcers show no organisms. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

24-hour esophageal pH monitoring is used to confirm the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). While this patient certainly has GERD given his history of heartburn and low gastric pH, GERD alone would not explain his endoscopic findings (e.g., thick gastric folds, several peptic ulcers). These findings are more suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome and 24-hour esophageal pH monitoring would not be of any further diagnostic value.

B) CORRECT:

Determining the fasting serum gastrin level is the best initial test for diagnosing gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), which this patient likely has. A 10-fold increase in gastrin levels is conclusive evidence of a gastrinoma, especially in combination with a gastric pH < 2. A secretin stimulation test (SST) may also be used in the diagnosis of ZES. However, it must be performed without acid suppression therapy and is not recommended in patients with severe manifestations of ZES.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of urine metanephrine levels (e.g., catecholamine metabolites) is indicated if the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is suspected. While pheochromocytoma can cause episodic diarrhea, this patient is missing other characteristic features, such as headache, palpitations, and hypertension, making this diagnosis unlikely. ZES, which this patient has, is associated with MEN-1, while pheochromocytoma is associated with MEN-2A and MEN-2B.

D) INCORRECT:

A urea breath test is a good screening test for Helicobacter pylori. However, the gold standard for detecting H. pylori is the histopathologic evaluation of endoscopic biopsies, which were already performed in this patient and came back negative (e.g., no organisms seen). There is no point in performing a screening test after already conducting the confirmation test.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum VIP levels would be indicated if there were suspicion of a VIPoma, a rare neuroendocrine tumor associated with MEN-1 that typically manifests with high-volume, watery diarrhea. In addition, ZES, which this patient has, is also associated with MEN-1. However, abdominal tenderness, heartburn, and this patient's upper endoscopic findings are not consistent with a VIPoma.
questions.hint: Several peptic ulcers, ulcers in unusual locations (i.e., jejunum), and thick gastric folds should raise suspicion for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening heartburn and abdominal pain for the past 4 months. During this period she has also had multiple episodes of greasy diarrhea. Six months ago, she had similar symptoms and was diagnosed with a duodenal ulcer. Her mother died of complications from uncontrolled hypoglycemia and had primary hyperparathyroidism. The patient does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Her only medications are pantoprazole and ranitidine. Her epigastric region is tender when palpated. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows a friable ulcer in the distal duodenum. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies in the serum
Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies in the serum
Parietal cell hyperplasia in the stomach

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are seen in pernicious anemia. They bind to intrinsic factor, thus blocking the binding of and absorption of vitamin B12. Although this patient's malabsorption puts her at risk of vitamin deficiencies, vitamin B12 deficiency causes signs of megaloblastic anemia and/or neurologic symptoms, which are not present in this patient. More importantly, pernicious anemia does not explain this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms or history of recurrent PUD.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies can be found in the serum of patients with celiac disease. This condition can manifest with symptoms of malabsorption, such as anemia, vitamin deficiencies, and in some individuals, steatorrhea, which this patient has. However, celiac disease would not explain this patient's history of recurrent PUD.

C) CORRECT:

Parietal cell hyperplasia in the stomach can be seen in ZES, which involves a gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor of the gastrointestinal tract. Hypergastrinemia leads to stimulation of parietal cells and excessive gastric acid production. As neuroendocrine tumors carry somatostatin receptors, radiolabeled octreotide can be used diagnostically to locate the tumor.
Image Description:

Gastric acid secretion (HCl) is stimulated by acetylcholine (in response to vagus nerve activity), gastrin (produced by G cells), and histamine (produced by ECL cells in response to vagus nerve activity). The decreasing pH of the gastric juice (due to HCl) acts as a negative feedback mechanism by stimulating D-cells to produce somatostatin, which directly inhibits G-cell activity. As gastric contents enter the duodenum, a variety of hormones are released (summarized at the bottom left of image), each with specific functions.

D) INCORRECT:

Noncaseating granulomas in the jejunum are the histological correlate of Crohn disease. Crohn disease typically manifests with diarrhea, which this patient reports. However, diarrhea in patients with Crohn disease is typically loose and watery, rather than greasy. Additionally, Crohn disease would not explain this patient's history of recurrent PUD.

E) INCORRECT:

Dystrophic calcification in the pancreas may be found in chronic pancreatitis. Multiple endocrine neoplasia is associated with pancreatic tumors. Both chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic tumors can cause impaired pancreatic enzyme secretion and thus symptoms of malabsorption (e.g., steatorrhea), which are seen in this patient. However, this patient's history of recurrent PUD is inconsistent with chronic pancreatitis.
questions.hint: Treatment-resistant peptic ulcer disease and features of malabsorption, combined with a family history suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia (primary hyperparathyroidism and pancreatic insulinoma), raises suspicion for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES).

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease. Antral-biopsy specimens are positive for Helicobacter pylori. She reports using substantial amounts of ibuprofen while training for a marathon.
She is diagnosed with multiple gastric and duodenal ulcers (figures 1 and 2) and is treated with a 14-day course of antibiotics and omeprazole for the H. pylori infection. She is instructed to continue taking omeprazole 40 mg daily.
She presents for follow-up 8 weeks later and reports no heartburn, abdominal pain, or bleeding. A complete blood count shows the return of hemoglobin to normal values. However, the serum gastrin level is 242 pg/mL (reference range, < 100).
Which one of the following strategies would be most useful to evaluate the patient’s elevated serum gastrin level?

choices.text: Remeasure the serum gastrin level 2 weeks after discontinuing omeprazole
Measure the serum chromogranin A level
Remeasure the serum gastrin level now

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A secretin-stimulation test is performed for evaluation of the Zollinger-Ellison syndrome to distinguish gastrinomas from other causes of elevated serum gastrin levels. This test can be done if the serum gastrin level remains elevated despite discontinuation of PPIs, although serum gastrin levels in patients with the syndrome typically exceed 1000 pg/mL, making this diagnosis less likely in patients with ulcers caused by nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or Helicobacter pylori infection.

B) CORRECT:

Gastrin is an intestinal hormone secreted into the blood by antral G cells in response to a meal or to a high gastric pH level. Therefore, many patients receiving long-term therapy with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), such as omeprazole, may have an elevated gastrin level. Confirmation of hypergastrinemia requires remeasuring the serum gastrin level at least 2 weeks after the PPI is discontinued. The gastrin level should be measured under fasting conditions because elevated levels are common postprandially.

Repeating the serum gastrin measurement is unlikely to be diagnostically useful in a patient who continues to take a PPI.

Key learning point: The most useful approach to evaluate the cause of an elevated serum gastrin level in a patient with gastroesophageal reflux disease who is receiving long-term omeprazole therapy is to remeasure the serum gastrin level at least 2 weeks after discontinuing the omeprazole (a proton pump inhibitor).

C) INCORRECT:

Serum chromogranin A is a tumor marker whose levels are often elevated in patients with gastrinomas but can also be elevated in patients who have other types of neuroendocrine tumors or who are receiving a PPI.

D) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is unlikely to be diagnostic in a patient who was already noted to have gastric and duodenal ulcers.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring a serum gastrin level is generally not advisable in a patient being treated with a PPI.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with repeated episodes of severe epigastric pain and chronic watery diarrhea. He requires high-dose proton pump inhibitors for presumed peptic ulcer disease. Endoscopy reveals persistent duodenal ulcers with no evidence of Helicobacter pylori. Abdominal imaging notes a 1.5 cm lesion in the head of the pancreas (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Serum gastrin
1000 ng/L
< 100 ng/L


Secretin stimulation test
Increase in gastrin > 200 ng/L
Increase in gastrin < 200 ng/L



Which of the following diagnoses best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Gastrinomas cause Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by excessive gastrin secretion leading to hyperstimulation of gastric acid production. This results in recurrent, refractory peptic ulcers, severe epigastric pain, and chronic watery diarrhea. The markedly elevated serum gastrin level and the paradoxical increase in gastrin following secretin administration confirm the diagnosis. The pancreatic lesion further supports the presence of a gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor.

Key learning point: A positive secretin stimulation test in the context of refractory peptic ulcers and diarrhea is indicative of a gastrinoma, which is associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucagon-secreting tumors typically present with weight loss, hyperglycemia, and necrolytic migratory erythema. The elevated serum gastrin levels, secretin-responsive hypergastrinemia, and duodenal ulcers suggest a gastrin-secreting tumor, not a glucagonoma.

C) INCORRECT:

VIP-secreting tumors cause WDHA syndrome (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria) due to excessive vasoactive intestinal peptide, which inhibits gastric acid secretion. The presence of persistent duodenal ulcers and significant acid hypersecretion, along with elevated serum gastrin levels, is inconsistent with a VIPoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Somatostatinomas inhibit gastrin, leading to hypochlorhydria, not acid hypersecretion. They often present with diabetes, steatorrhea, and gallstones. The elevated serum gastrin levels, positive secretin stimulation test, and recurrent duodenal ulcers indicate a gastrin-secreting tumor, not a somatostatinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with severe epigastric pain that has worsened over the past 2 days. He has been treated for peptic ulcer disease three times in the past year with standard therapy, including Helicobacter pylori eradication. Despite appropriate treatment, he continues to experience recurrent abdominal pain and has developed watery diarrhea occurring 4-5 times daily over the past month. His current medications include omeprazole 20 mg daily. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows significant epigastric tenderness without guarding, rebound, or rigidity. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 11.8 g/dL and normal lipase. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease can cause abdominal pain and diarrhea, but typically presents with inflammatory bowel symptoms rather than recurrent peptic ulcer disease. The pattern of therapy-resistant ulcers following appropriate H. pylori treatment is not characteristic of Crohn disease.

B) INCORRECT:

H. pylori reinfection could cause recurrent peptic ulcer disease, but would not typically cause the secretory diarrhea seen in this patient. Reinfection rates are low following successful eradication therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic adenocarcinoma typically presents with progressive weight loss, jaundice, and new-onset diabetes mellitus rather than recurrent peptic ulcer disease. When diarrhea occurs, it is usually steatorrhea from pancreatic exocrine insufficiency rather than the watery secretory diarrhea seen in this patient. The normal lipase also does not favor pancreatic adenocarcinoma, which often causes pancreatic duct obstruction and elevated lipase. The year-long history of recurrent ulcers is not consistent with pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's presentation of recurrent, therapy-resistant peptic ulcer disease following appropriate treatment including H. pylori eradication, combined with secretory diarrhea, is highly suggestive of gastrinoma. Gastrinomas secrete excessive gastrin, leading to acid hypersecretion and recurrent ulcers that are resistant to standard therapy. The next appropriate step would be gastroenterology consultation for fasting serum gastrin and gastric pH measurement.

E) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome can cause secretory diarrhea, but typically presents with flushing and does not cause recurrent peptic ulcer disease. The combination of therapy-resistant ulcers and diarrhea is more suggestive of gastrinoma.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the ED with abdominal pain and is found to have a 2-cm pancreatic mass on CT. He reports a 4-month history of intermittent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and 10-pound weight loss. Which clinical finding would most strongly suggest this tumor is a gastrinoma?

choices.text: Multiple peptic ulcers in unusual locations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic diarrhea with steatorrhea can occur with multiple pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, including gastrinoma and somatostatinoma, making this finding non-specific for gastrinoma diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Recurrent hypoglycemic episodes are characteristic of insulinoma, which secretes excess insulin causing endogenous hyperinsulinism and Whipple triad. Gastrinomas do not affect blood glucose levels.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Multiple peptic ulcers in unusual locations such as the distal duodenum or jejunum are highly characteristic of gastrinoma. This finding, along with therapy-resistant ulcer disease, strongly suggests Zollinger-Ellison syndrome caused by excess gastrin secretion.

D) INCORRECT:

Profuse watery diarrhea with hypokalemia describes WDHA syndrome, characteristic of VIPoma. VIP causes secretory diarrhea exceeding 700 mL daily with associated electrolyte disturbances and achlorhydria.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperglycemia with skin rash describes glucagonoma, which causes diabetes and necrolytic migratory erythema. The characteristic rash presents as spreading erythema that becomes crusty with bronze-colored induration.
